The car parking charge is crazy but when we complained that someone kept parking their car in our designated space we got a 20 dollar refund. Also to to Charge 10 dollars for the miniature golf is ridiculous! Surely this should be included free of charge, as there is precious little other entertainment on the site particularly in the evenings. Concierge was excellent and helped us a lot. Finally, the huge lagoon in the centre of the resort is wasted, it should be made into a swimming pool worthy of a 4 Star?? resort. Really enjoyed San Diego though, lovely area and would recommend the IHOP breakfast just a mile away. .

Reviews.Title: “Acceptable accomodations, if you get a deal”
Reviews.Author: 3littlebears
Reviews.Content: Booked via Priceline and ended up here. I would concur with other posts, which indicated that this place is ok, if you get a deal...well below rack rate. The rooms were pleasant, but I would have been seriously disappointed had I booked at full price and expected a luxury resort/spa experience. Our room/bungalow had been updated, but still felt dated. Carpets were stained and overall room did not feel particularly clean. I would only stay here again, if I got a serious deal. $20 parking fee is ridiculous.

Reviews.Title: “We had a great time, where did you go?!”
Reviews.Author: iwanttogoonholiday
Reviews.Content: We stayed here for a week in 2004 and really enjoyed it so when booking our holiday for this year we thought we'd come back (we also spent a week up in Anaheim). After reading some of the reviews on here we were a bit worried that we had made a mistake, but we've stayed at places which have received mixed reviews before and always enjoyed ourselves. I am so glad that we went back as we had a great time. Reading some of the negative reviews I wonder whether we stayed at the same place! We are a family of four (mum, dad and 2 'kids' in our 20's) and so we had 2 rooms. We were pleased to discover that our rooms were within the same bungalow so we shared the same front door which opened into a small passageway and then our rooms were on either side. We had lovely views of one of the lagoons and we were right next door to the waterfall pool. The rooms were plenty big enough, with a king sized bed and a sofa in mum and dad's room and two queen sized beds and a smaller sofa in our room. We had mini fridges in both of our rooms which we always kept well stocked with food and drink - a trip or 2 to the nearby Vons saved loads on buying breakfast and lunch everyday. Our room also had a small sink area (aside from the bathroom) and a microwave - which was handy for popcorn on the beach in the evening! We liked the way the sink was separate from the main bathroom, allowing 2 people to get ready at once, rather than one taking up the whole bathroom! Speaking of the bathroom, we LOVE the complimentary toiletries provided, they smell great!! A few negative points were that the plumbing was quite noisy - we could hear when the other room was using the shower, and if both rooms had the shower running at the same time you lost water pressure. A couple of times we found that the maids had forgotten to replenish one of the toiletry items, if we wanted to we could have phoned to have them replaced, but we didn't bother. Yes, the carpets had probably seen better days, but given the type of resort you spend a lot of time barefoot or in flipflops and you don't take your shoes off before you come in the room so what do you expect? It certainly wasn't so bad that you didn't want to stand on it, they just weren't as clean as our carpets at home! I'm not going to complain about the cost of parking (mainly because it was included in our package from Virgin holidays!) but anyway, we are used to paying at hotels. Yes, it's an annoying added expense, but at least you get a dedicated space right by your room. What is really annoying is when people park in your space! As we had 2 rooms, we technically had 2 parking spaces next to each other, but one night we came back and found someone had parked their huge SUV not only in one of our spaces, but blocking both of our spaces! Please park where you're supposed to! We found the concierge to be very helpful, and even let us use his phone to call home when we mentioned that whilst using one of the phones in the lobby, the person the other end couldn't hear, and was there another phone to use. The grounds are beautiful and we always saw people tending to the plants around the resort. We didn't find the pool dirty like some have said - yes, there was the odd leaf etc, floating around, but surely that's to be expected with the amount of surrounding foliage? All in all, we had a great time and were sad to leave. We'd definitely like to come back again!

Reviews.Title: “Relaxing stay”
Reviews.Author: ChgotoSD
Reviews.Content: I went to Paradise Point to relax and get away from Chicago. I am an adult over 50 yrs old and came alone. I wanted a quiet place, where I could walk safely and enjoy to view of the bay or the beautiful landscaping. If I had been looking for night time entertainment I would have been disappointed, but I went for this atmosphere purposely. I also experienced some difficulty at check-in with the desk staff and the availability of the room. Originally after check in, I was disappointed in the room, this was due to the low light at 5pm which did not do the room any favors and my tired state. As the next day arrived the shabby chic room was exactly what I had expected. I did think the drapes could have better covered the windows but that is all. All rooms are bungalow-like and have a lanai looking out on gardens or lagoons or the mission bay beach. The evening I arrived I ate at Baleen, the chilean sea bass was excellent. On the point near Baleen there was a wedding being performed which could be seen from their patio area. What a sweet way to start a vacation. I talked to a few "locals", Paradise Point is a destination for California, Arizona and Nevada locals for weekend retreats. They arrive in their SUVs along with b-b-ques to party the weekend at the beach. One family had been coming to this area for at least two generations for weekend get-aways. They conveyed that the prices can vary widely for the accomodations and recommended shopping around for the best price. There are three very clean pools: one communal pool with 3 fantasic fountains (this one is very shallow), a childrens pool and an adult only pool. There is a secluded bar near the bigger pool. There is mini golf and multiple person bikes to be rented. The spa staff is knowledgeable and their offerings are wonderful. The pricing was about what I would pay in an upscale salon in Chicago, their spa was better than any of those Chicago spas. The lagoons have nice outcroppings with comfortable patio furniture which makes a great place for morning coffee and reading the paper. The concierge staff was extremely helpful at all times and have discounted tickets to some local events as well as specialty prices with taxi firms. The Old Town Trolley tour picks up on the property as well as a bus tour to Mexico. I had a wonderfully restful visit to Paradise Point and would love to go back again sometime in the future.

Reviews.Title: “Do you know there's a skunk here?”
Reviews.Author: vincekelly
Reviews.Content: There's a $250 fine if you smoke inside the rooms. We'll say that's fair enough so I was sittin outside my room smokin a cigarette and when I turn to my left, what do I see? A damn skunk! I don't know if I saw the same one twice or two different ones but it scared the sh*t out of me. The next morning, I saw a opossum that looked straight at me and then kept goin on his way. There's considerable walking at this hotel so upon checkout, I called for a bellhop to come get me and my luggage...he took (and I was lookin at my watch) 45 mins. to get to my room, even though I was calling (almost harassing) the front desk to send him. Save your money, $300 will get you a much better place.

Reviews.Title: “not ready for prime time”
Reviews.Author: Mikey42
Reviews.Content: Insufficient housekeeping staff to have overpriced rooms ready for the 4pm check in. As a front desk employee put it "check in just "starts" at 4 pm (long line)..that doesn't mean the rooms are ready. There were several crowded pool facilities, but since we had no room card key, we had to just wait around until almost five o'clock. A food credit was offered to make up for the inconvenience, but it was "accidentally" charged to our room instead of credited (check the bill carefully!) Ice bucket was missing from room, but it didn't matter, because ice machines were too hard to find and soda machines empty. Room had "adjoining" door in bad repair & peeling paint and grody grout did not effect a real "resort" atmosphere.

Reviews.Title: “excellent location, service very hit and miss”
Reviews.Author: waltons39
Reviews.Content: we stayed for 5 nights and had a lovely garden room, quite near the ocean and pools, in orchid area.. we had a great stay and would recommend the hotel, but the service was frustrating at times, in that it could be excellent but it could also be realoly awful. This applied to the barefoot grill and the room and pool service. The Balleen restaurant and the concierge were excellent. DO complain, ask for a manager, they listen and respond. Its the only way to get an improvement, by the time you write on here, its too late. The watersports facility is good but its not really a bathing beach, more a relax and look at the ocean type of beach. The reviews on here about the layout and orienteering are harsh, it is well signposted and well lt, you dont really need to get in to your 4x4 truck to go to the coffee cart, there are paths!!

Reviews.Title: “Renamed 'Purgatory Point' resort”
Reviews.Author: asia4me
Reviews.Content: Spent two expensive nights at the resort in April 2007 as part of a family trip. I cannot find a single good thing to say about it but many many many terrible ones. Where to start? First the money. This is a very expensive resort $300+ and upon checking in we are told that there is a $20 per day parking fee, are you kidding me? Maybe they park your car and wash it at night? Of course not. It is dishonest for a hotel to add these kind of extra fees on top of the room charge without telling you about them when you book. There is a mini golf on site. My nephew and nieces wanted to play, surprise surprise you need to pay $9 a head for a pathetic little course right on by the road. Want to use the gym? Sure, $15 please. By the way the gym is the only nice thing in the whole property, i.e. it is new and has new equipment but it should be free, as in every hotel in the world. The rest of the place is shockingly in need of a remodel and not just a coat of paint. Our two rooms smelled horribly musty. We asked to be moved, the next two rooms were musty too but not as bad. The furniture is in bad shape, the bed covers very suspicious, the bathrooms drab, the walls paper thin and we found tons of ants in the bathroom the next morning. Our room overlooked a murky pound. The gardens are dull and in need of some landscaping. They do however mow the lawn at 7am, thank you!! I am glad we did not spend the extra money for a room with sea view as the beach is dirty and the water polluted. Needless to say that we shortened our stay there and checked out the following day.

Reviews.Title: “Should be called Paradox Resort”
Reviews.Author: SkaryKitty
Reviews.Content: All I can say is avoid this hotel unless you booked through Priceline and you are stuck with it as we were. Only good thing I can say about this place is the price we paid which was about the same as a motel nearby. The rooms are small for a "resort". We saw ceiling light fixtures falling off, light switches not working, paint peeling, etc. The front door into the room was blocked by a chair which obviously didn't belong in its place - I moved it to another place which made more sense (me being an interior designer). Is the pool salt water or is it just dirty (if you know what I mean)? One last thing, the hotel reception told us that we could walk to Sea World which is about a mile away. We decided to drive and realize that the walk is along a busy highway with a very narrow sidewalk. This is totally unsafe especially if you have kids or at night returning from the park. Do yourself a favor and stay away from this place.

Reviews.Title: “Family Only”
Reviews.Author: Gigz
Reviews.Content: A simple message to any young couples who are recomended this hotel as place to stay by a tour company. Dont go. This is a strictly family orientated hotel more like a Butlins to any UK/Irish readers. The only bar in the place is the barefoot grill which closes at 22:30 and is still full of children until this time. The hotel is located close to sea world but not to the city for shopping going out etc. Tip Garnet is 10/15 mins in a taxi away and has some lively bars. The grounds and the pool were beautiful and the adults only pool gives you a reprieve from the screaming children. All in all, nice for a family holiday look elsewhere for anything else

Reviews.Title: “Very Disappointed and still owed a refund 2 months later”
Reviews.Author: Jayne-NYC
Reviews.Content: We saw Paradise Point in a brochure and researched it on the web. All the glossy images do not live up to the reality. This is a 1960's looking complex with basic concrete bugalows for rooms. Essentially it's a tropical Centre Parks. Our room was adjoined to another and we could hear everything through the door due to the large gaps around it. Rooms were big but very dated and in need of repair. You also have to pay for everything, including parking and the gym. I have stayed numerous hotels and none, absolutely none, charge to use the gym! The beach was awful and manmade. You can see what look likes oil lines on the sand from the pollution in the water. There is also construction of a swimming pool taking place, nice and noisy during our stay and they couldn't move us. We rented a car to get away from the noise, which the hotel suggested and said they would refund us for. 2 months later, and countless phonecalls, we have not received the refund. This is extremely poor service and unacceptable. As a final note, do not visit San Diego in May (May Grey) or June (June gloom). Its cold and miserable. Something all the locals know but none of the visitors!

Reviews.Title: “This is not Pardise to me”
Reviews.Author: screenname66
Reviews.Content: I initially tried to go through the toll free number to make my reservations but had so many problems - first 20+ minutes on hold on 2 seperate occasions, then completely untrained personell once I was able to finally make contact - I booked a 3 night 4 day stay with my husband and 2 small children, ages 5 and 7. I asked if they had a family package deal for Sea World, and she said she had heard something about a package deal, but said she did not know much about it, so I should just call Sea World myself and see if they knew if Paradise had a package deal with them. She was really starting to bug me. At this point I had been trying to get a reservation completed with her for over 40 minutes but she seemed really confused. I asked her if she could please get a manager for me to speak with to find out more about their Sea World package and she sat the phone down and yelled into the other room to ask someone to yell back and tell her about the passes. I should have just cancelled at this point, but the web site had it listed as a 4.5 star resort, so I chalked it up to a poor employee. She came back on the line and said - OK, its a 2 day family splash package. It is a 2 day Sea World pass pack that includes 2 adult and 2 childrens tickets and it increases your daily rate to $259 per day over 4 days payment. I asked her if she knew what the regular rate for Sea World was and she seemed to lock up at the confusing question I possed. Begining to tire from this entire transaction, I just said OK, yea, lets do the 2 day Sea World family splash pass for 2 adults and 2 kids. About a week prior to our trip, I called the hotel just to check on everything and the long hold cycle started again - I gave it 20 minutes and just called the hotel directly and asked for the manager. Sergio got on the line and appoligized for the problems and checked my reservation to make sure it was what we had thought. Yep, we were all in, including the 2 day Sea World Splash pass. On the day we arrived, we went to the bell stand to get our tickets. He told us that it was only a 5 minute walk at the most to get to Sea World from where we were standing with our 5 and 7 year old daughters. He gave us our tickets and said to come back the following day for the other tickets as they are bar coded and once issued cannot be replaced. That seemed fine - so off we went. While the back side of Sea World is more like about 20 minutes walking and piggy backing our children, to get to the front entrance it was closer to 40 minutes of walking. Once at the gate we gave the attendant our tickets and she said that was only good to get in my husband and myself - the kids were an additional $96 - I was sure that the bellman had made an innocent error, so I kept the receipt so that I could clear it up when we returned to our hotel that afternoon. I contacted the front desk once back in my room and they said that the Splash pack was only good for 2 adult tickets 2 days, not the 2 adults, 2 children that we had been told. I was really bugged, but thought what the heck - we are here now, we'll just get our tickets and buy for the kids The following day we went back to the bell station to get our final 2 adult tickets - we were told that there we no more tickets for us, because the 2 day Spash Pack is for 2 adult tickets only - total. Non of this maked any sense what so ever. 2 days is 48 hours - family is typically 2 adults 2 children To help us through our obvious irritation, we received 4 tickets to use on their property. The 4 tickets we good for 4 /30 minute sessions on their out door basketball courts. Seriously

Reviews.Title: “Loved Paradise Point”
Reviews.Author: loveinsandiego
Reviews.Content: My eight year old son and I stayed at the Paradise Point at the beginning of June. What can we say other than it was beautiful. The views from the bay were breathtaking. The way the bungalows were set up I felt that it was very private and only a few steps away from the bay. Pools were very nice considering that it never really gets hot over there they were heated so that you could still enjoy a swim when you weren't on the go. The grounds were well kept with the feel of peacefulness and relaxation after a long day at a theme parks. The rooms were kept very clean, the staff was very helpful and polite. In fact we are planning our trip for next year. Excellent place to stay for families, located very close to everything.

Reviews.Title: “Well under par”
Reviews.Author: vacationer71
Reviews.Content: Paradise Point dramatically oversells and overprices itself. Our bungalow had many things outdated, missing or out of order and management had a casual attitude towards remedying those deficiencies. The restaurants are mediocre in cuisine and service. The roads are laid out in a thoroughly serpentine and perplexing fashion -- and with essentially no street lights, you are certain to get lost when coming home at night. On the plus side, the spa service was nice, the views and beach access are nice if you are in a beachside bungalow and much of the property is beautiful. The beach is not exactly a bathing beach, though, and non-Californians need to be aware that there is no such thing as a private beach in California -- non-guests can and do have access to the beach right up to six feet from your doorstep. With renovations, some added housekeeping and engineering staff, and a new team in at the restaurants, this could be a champion place which earns its rates.

Reviews.Title: “Some good, some bad”
Reviews.Author: ThePoolGirl
Reviews.Content: I thought the grounds and pools were lovely. The casual restaurant had dull food but had a very pretty view. We stayed in a "garden studio suite" which actually from the couch offered a view of Mission Bay. The decor was pleasant. The size of the room was very nice. I booked early to get a good rate, but right before I stayed there the room rates were dropped on many travel search engines. The deal was not offered to me because Paradise Point takes a deposit on the room well in advance of your arrival and no refunds 7 days before arrival. But, Dear Annette, don't dump rates on Expedia and Travelocity and not offer those same rates to savvy frequent travellors. We feel screwed over even when you offer an upgrade because its not a real upgrade. We are only getting what we paid for and nothing more. You dumped the regular room rates and offered me the "discounted" rate for a better room but I'd have rather had the room I booked at the dumped rate with the two beds instead of the king + sleeper sofa. I cannot recommend a hotel that baits and switches. And travellors, please do not book early or in advance for this hotel as they offer such wonderful discounts for last minute travel.

Reviews.Title: “Very pleased with our stay”
Reviews.Author: hello12355555
Reviews.Content: My sister and I stayed for a couple days 5/24, 5/25. We were a bit skeptical after reading some of the reviews. From the time we arrived to the time we left we could not figure out why some of the reviews were poor. The grounds are beautiful, the customer service was great. We were given free drinks (2) because our server forgot about us. No big deal, we were there during dinner just sitting outside the Balene enjoying the fire. We weren't there for dinner, only a cocktail. I call that good customer service, they made up for their mistake. We did not have kids with us but noticed how family oriented the place is. We thought it would be wonderful for families with children. There is so much to do. Bring your bikes and beach toys. In conclusion, it's a wonderful place. You get what you put out there. Go.... with the plan to have fun and you will. Oh, we called the front desk twice. Once to turn off the porch light (can't be done from inside) and another to fix the water faucet. Both times they arrived VERY QUICKLY, did the job then later called to make sure it was done and we were satisfied.

Reviews.Title: “O.K. for Families, A Bit Musty for Price”
Reviews.Author: WestCoast11
Reviews.Content: We wanted a luxerious, one week vacation for my husband and I, my son 4, and our exchange student 16 for the end of February 2007. Weather was cold but sunny. Booked largest bungalow on beach, had two separate areas, one bedroom with separate vanity and closet, and Student slept on comfortable pull out and his own vanity and closet space. Toilet and bath was shared between the two rooms. Space is larger than it looks on the website. Kitchen unit had nothing. We bought plastic bowls, dish soap and sponge, cereal, milk, snacks, and ate breakfast in the room each morning. Maid and front desk staff were excellent. However, the bungalows were old, toilets back up occasionally (water only not sewage) causing water damage to be dried out and leaving musty smell. Decore nice, modern, and comfortable but the unit just smelled and felt a bit old, musty and damp (my husband didn't think it was noticable). I guess I prefer newer construction. But what can you expect from an updated resort right on the water? Water view, beach front, and gardens were spectacular. Great central location. Casual dining on site and for room service o.k. Student thought hamburger awesome. TV channels very limited, no plug in for playstation 2. Pools seem nice. The heated one was too cold but we spent some time in the whirlpool with everyone else. Good resort for families with older kids (7-16 probably ideal), adults on their own or sharing with other couples. Less expensive room options around the site as good as the beach option. Rent a minivan. Driving is easy to all attractions. Ask the resort for a reduced parking rate for longer stays. They are very helpful and keen to ensure you enjoy your stay. Meal Tips: authentic, inexpensive mexican food at Valentinos in Mission Bay; and, fresh Italian take out back to your room at Cafe Bella, Garnet Ave Mission Bay. See all Sea World shows and consider two day pass with backstage tour. Well worth it. Loved Legoland. Both Sea World and Legoland have huge, excellent play areas for young kids. You could spend several hours at these locations with toddlers and preschoolers so bring something to read. Carlsbad shopping outlet is great and close to Legoland. The mall has a Diner that has the best milkshakes! Las Americas is even better shopping south of San Diego (quick drive). Coronado bridge and beach great. Zoo fun (avoid the petting zoo, disappointing compared to local farms). We did not go to the wild animal park. Old Town is very quiet and nice. Great mexican food everywhere. Our four year old could not follow the walking tour (too boring) but my husband and our student thought it was great. The shops have interesting art and pottery, and unique imports. We will return to San Diego when the weather is warmer. Lots still to see and do in the years to come.

Reviews.Title: “Great place for kids! Great place to relax!”
Reviews.Author: OCMommyof2
Reviews.Content: I have been to Paradise Point many, many times and my family and I enjoy it every time. The rooms are definately not luxurious, but they are beachy and comfortable. We have only stayed in the bungalows on the bay front, so we do not know what it is like anywhere else. The unit that we get has very large windows facing the bay with beautiful views. There is a sliding glass door that leads to the bay. Outside the slider you have your patio with chairs and small table, then grass, then the sand on the beach, then the bay. Inside we have a kitchenette with a small fridge, sink, microwave, storage and counter space. I can not tell you how wonderful it is sitting on those patio chairs watching my 2 year old and 5 year old playing in the sand together with sail boats and rowing teams passing by in the bay. I find that view so calming and relaxing... that is why I love it there so much. The inside of the room has a king bed for my husband and I and a sleeper sofa for the kids. The property grounds make you feel as if you are in Hawaii... very lush. My husband and I enjoy their fine dining restaurant , Baleen, because we can bring our kids there without worrying about it. They have many other activities there like a minature putting green, swimming pool, boat rentals, etc. I can not believe this place is rated so low. I love it there. Yes, the furniture in the rooms are a little banged up, but I'll take that any day to get that relaxing bayfront view. The property is also situated on its own private island, so you are away from all the riff raff of Mission and Pacific Beach. There are no homeless or seedy people drinking alcohol & hanging around a public restroom next door like there is at Tripadvisors #1 rated Pacific Terrace Hotel. The rooms are not luxurious like the Pacific Terrace, but to me, nothing beats opening that sliding glass door to the bay, putting my feet in the sand and enjoying the sunsets and the beautiful relaxing views. It is very calming and that is what you need with two young kids. We always go off season so we feel like we own the beach as it is very quiet and not a whole lot of people around. At night, we build a fire in one of the fire pits that are situated on the beach in front of the units and roast marshmallows for Smores. The kids love it. My husband and I love it. Smores and wine go well together. Go figure. If you do not want to be around riff raff, then stay here, but if you want luxury, then stay elsewhere.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful gardens, musty, moldy room”
Reviews.Author: DonnaSunValley
Reviews.Content: We booked a garden lanai room at Paradise Point off their website. It was supposed to be $250 "total" per the website. The first thing the woman at reception noted to me was an additional $20 fee for parking. Apparently "total" does not mean all charges. When we opened the door to the entry way of our room we were blasted with the musty odor of mold. I'm allergic to mold. Thus, I didn't really enjoy being in our room at all. My nose ran the entire time. I got up at 6:00 a.m. and went outside to read to get away from the mold. The $8 million upgrade apparently didn't make it to our room as one of the chairs looked as though someone's cat had sharpened their claws on it . Other pieces were really banged up. The thin, poorly insulated walls brought us a little closer to the family with small children and a baby next door than we might have wished. How many times can small children open and close a hotel room door while their neighbors are trying to take a little afternoon nap? We lost count but we were awake and trying. The woman at check in put us in a room on a lagoon. She told me that she loves those rooms. The lagoon was an algae filled mud hole surrounded by bare dirt. The algae was huge and biologically fascinating but less than aesthetically pleasing. I would happily go back to Paradise Point, walk around the truly beautiful grounds, other than the lagoons area, maybe have a tropical drink in the bar, and then drive away to a fresh, clean room somewhere else in the San Diego area.

Reviews.Title: “Great Mother/Daughter Getaway!”
Reviews.Author: swnymph
Reviews.Content: My teenaged daughter and I had a great time at the Paradise Point. As I drive all week long, the last thing I wanted on vacation was a rental car, so we took cabs everywhere - really, with the parking fee at the hotel, and seaworld, I think we came out ahead on that. When our cab pulled up from the airport, the bell staff greeted us and loaded our luggage on a golf cart while directing us to check-in. The front desk staff were quite friendly to us, and the bellman who took us to our room was wonderful! We spent the whole first day exploring the resort - jellyfish season runs from February-April, so if you go any time outside that, you won't have jellyfish on the beach. We enjoyed looking at them, really. The harbor on site has rental boats, so we went out on the bay in a kayak one day and a sailboat a different day. The prices on these boats are quite reasonable - the power boats and waterski runs can get more expensive. We stayed from Monday night to Friday afternoon, so we had lots of time to look around this place (we did spend 2 full days at seaworld). The best part for my daughter really was the Barefoot Cafe - yes it is slow and pricey (I expect to pay too much at a resort restaurant, don't you?), but there is a waterfall and pond outside - the birds and fish are great, and there was even a huge lobster in there. I didn't have much company at meals because the girl kept jumping up to look at the wildlife - as did most of the kids there. If you hate kids, this is not a good place for you to eat! The staff was really friendly. I had read many reviews of this hotel before we went, so I was prepared for the grounds to be wonderful (they were) and the rooms to have some cosmetic issues (they did). Our room was really big, and the bed was comfortable. We had a coffee maker and a refrigerator - I never tested the TV as we were so busy. Room service breakfast was really quite fast! The housekeeping staff were not the best - when they saw I had used the coffee maker, they cleaned it, but forgot to leave more coffee and cups. Next day I left a note and there were no more problems. The room was clean, including the bathroom, but there was a bit of rust on the hinges, could use a coat of paint. The pools were not too crowded (this was spring break time and things were a bit more crowded on Friday when we were leaving). During the day there were lots of kids in the hot tub at the main lagoon pool, but there is an adults only pool with another hot tub if you want to avoid crowds and kids. Both of those pools are heated, as is the waterfall pool. There were plenty of towels (you are asked to leave them at the pool, so having a beach towel to wrap up in after swimming is a good idea), and the pools were as clean as any pool you are sharing with other people - better than the public pool in my town. I will happily return to this resort - next time with my husband, teen son, and 4 year old twins!

Reviews.Title: “I had a good experience at this resort.”
Reviews.Author: doggydogface
Reviews.Content: On a recomendation from a friend,I made a last minute reservation for two rooms here during easter vacation. I was a little nervous since I had read some negative reviews on this website. I called up the hotel's reservation line and got a rate of $169.00 each for two non-bayview rooms (the bay view rooms were sold out). Our rooms were clean and comfortable. One was bigger,and had a walk in closet. My mother took the smaller room and my wife and daughter and I took the bigger one. The bed was reasonably comfortable, but the pull out bed that my daughter slept on was not due to a very thin matress. I would recomend getting a room with two queens if you needed to sleep more than two people. The big room had a little private porch that I enjoyed sitting in in the afternoon. Our rooms were in the Orchid village part of the resort and the girl at the front desk said that it was quiet area away from the main pool, and it was. We enjoyed our rooms and I can only sumise that there must be some good rooms and some bad rooms at this resort The Baleen restaurant was expensive, but the food was excellent. Room service food was good, but pricy. At many of the self contained resorts in Southern Ca (Hotel del Coronando and Ritz Carlton Laguna Niguel come to mind) you are going to spend a fortune if you buy all your meals there. We brought food and wine with us (there are refridgerators in the rooms. Also,bring your own putters to play the resort putting course. They charge $9.00 a putter. I did not find trash on the beach as was mentioned in the previous review and enjoyed walking on the beach (which by the way is on a bay; no waves). I found this resort to be a peaceful place to retreat to after spending a day exploring San Diego and I would return here.

Reviews.Title: “E.G., Worst Hotel Experience of my Life!”
Reviews.Author: Glamour_Girl247
Reviews.Content: When we first drove up to the hotel the grounds were beautiful. But then when we walked to the front desk the staff was very rude and gave us hardly any help at all. After we checked in we drove to our room. With no help from the staff we drug our luggage in. My first impression was the old dirty carpet and mud outside the door. The bathrooms were not much better than a gas station. The kitchen had moths on the light bulb. We got there late so the first thing we did was go to bed. In my daughters bed there was no pillow so i called the maid service and 2 hours later we got the pillow. So much for sleeping because our neighbors kept us up all night partying. We called the front desk and they didn't answer. The next day we hoped it would be a better day. Me and my kids decided to go the pool. Well, the pool was crowded and you could hardly get around. The first time I noticed a child pee in the pool I grabbed my kids and we left the pool. I have to say the only good thing I have to say about Paradise point is the food at the restaurant Baleen. We checked out three days early and headed to the Westgate Hotel, San Diego, where we had a very wonderful experience. Stay Away!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Reviews.Title: “Find someplace else”
Reviews.Author: Dallyn
Reviews.Content: We booked our room in November. Our confirmation stated that we had a one bedroom overlook. When we got to our room, we found that we â€œoverlookedâ€� a hedge and the 6 lane road it partially obscured. I called the front desk and was informed that â€œoverlookâ€� just meant you could see some of the grounds. The frame of the sofa bed in our room was broken, making the bed nonfunctional. As I lay on the floor with one of my kids trying to sleep, the excessive road noise made me envision that I was in some cheap roadside motel rather than a Noble House Resort. It took two trips to the front desk, a phone call and two trips by maintenance personnel to remedy the situation. We were initially promised a new room so we packed our belongings. Then we were told a replacement sofa had been found. Finally we were told they would just have someone repair it. The first repair attempt failed, prompting a second, successful attempt later in the day. On April 1 we visited the Lagoon Beach. The amount of trash on the beach was unacceptable. My children made the best of it by making a game as to who could pick up the most trash. Unfortunately, the fire pits on the beach had not had the ashes removed recently. As the wind would blow, the kids would get speckled with soot. They washed off in the water. We later found the sign indicating that the water may be contaminated due to surface runoff. Thankfully none of the children became ill.

Reviews.Title: “Disappointed in Paradise”
Reviews.Author: NapaValleyTravelBug
Reviews.Content: Paradise Point has definitely seen better days. Evidence of deferred maintenance -- crumbling buildings, stagnant ponds, and moldy-smelling rooms -- was visible throughout the resort. Our "Lagoon view room" was adjacent to an algae-filled drainage ditch. When we asked for another room, we were transferred to one next to a construction site. Then there are the additional charges -- $5 per hour for a bald, flat basketball; $9 for a putter and golfball for the 18-hole putting course. The bright spot was the staff. They were consistently helpful and cheery.

Reviews.Title: “Relaxing oasis with some minor flaws”
Reviews.Author: ATSChicago
Reviews.Content: Recently stayed at the Paridise Point in San Diego with my wife and two daughters. Overall, we enjoyed our stay. The grounds are beautiful and spacious with birds of paradise flowers everywhere the eye can see. We took advantage of all the property offered including swimming pool, spa, tennis, biking, miniature golf, beach and basketball. Food was good but as typical for this type of resort; prices were just north of outrageous. Ditto for spa services. Staff was very accommodating and always pleasant. The primary complaint for us surrounds the rooms. The bed was awful and the sleeper sofa bed was worse. Uncomfortable bedding and poor sleep really had a big effect on our vacation. In general the rooms could use some enhancements as it relates to furnishings and amenities to justify the price.

Reviews.Title: “Had a good time at the conference”
Reviews.Author: jasper87
Reviews.Content: We just returned from staying at the Paradise Point Resort, and I didn't find the negatives the other posters had mentioned, other than the typical resort charges. My room was very comfortable in Hibiscus Village, and housekeeping was attentive and thorough. The weather wasn't all that great, but that's not something they control. Almost every staff member we encountered as polite, helpful and friendly. I was impressed. Our meals were good. The resort was hard to navigate at first, so rely on your map. The only negatives are typical resort charges -- parking charges for a "nearby" spot (however, the Hyatt charges much more for a parking garage -- at least these spots are close to the room), and the pricing in the bars. Soda was $4, and domestic beer was $7. My friend had a margarita, and it was almost $10. That was a bit steep. Overall, we had a pleasant stay. I'd stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “Amazing Spa Experience”
Reviews.Author: bitties
Reviews.Content: I went to the Spa Terre for my sister's bachelorette party--it was amazing! the entire place is beautiful, and you feel so removed and secluded from the busy San Diego area. The grounds are gorgeous, very clean and well maintained. The staff was so nice--we have 11 women who all changed their reservations and spa treatements many times, and the Spa staff (Erin the manager is so sweet) completely accommodated all our requests. I reccommend reserving the private area--they served us with fresh fruit and vegetables, and we spent the day in our own private wood spa filled with flowers. I also reccommend the Chococlate Ice Cream pedicure and a facial with Melodie. We sat in the spa, layed out by the pool, and spent time in both the wet and dry saunas. But be warned: it IS really expensive, the entire resort is not cheap, but completely worth it (and I LIVE in San Diego). My boyfriend and I are going for a weekend just to be pampered and get away from life. If you're stressed, it is totally worth every penny. I can't wait to go again.

Reviews.Title: “A Good Time at Paradise Point”
Reviews.Author: foxtrotfs
Reviews.Content: We spent 3 nights during a lodging conference with several hundred attendees. Our room was nice and in good condition... right on the bay. The grounds were vast and lovely. The main restaurant was closed for a private function at dinner leaving the Barefoot Bar and Grill WOEFULLY understaffed for the other resort guests who were interested in eating on-site. I would recommend dining elsewhere.

Reviews.Title: “Purgatory Point Would Be More Accurate”
Reviews.Author: TripBlazer
Reviews.Content: I would echo the previous review in every detail. "Prepare to be gouged" is spot-on. $20/day for a parking spot (see photo) -- not even for valet parking, but just to park yourself next to your room. $15/day for the tiny exercise room. Yes, that's per day, not per stay. You get one day's fee off if you book one of the overpriced "spa" packages. Big deal, since the spa services themselves cost many times what they would cost in the outside world. And the prices at their "casual" outdoor restaurant are what you would normally expect from a fine dining experience. My wife and I spent $73 for two appetizers, two soups (nearly inedible), one order of luke-warm, flavorless coffee, and two salads that we split -- no main course. Our room was nothing special, though the rate was what we normally spend in Hawaii. The bathroom paint was disintegrating and peeling off, the hinges on the door were completely rusted, and the furniture was shabby at best. What the previous reviewer didn't mention is that this is one of those resorts where everything is inconveniently located -- it's all spread out over many acres. Your room is likely to be in a little building far from the main lobby, spa, exercise room, pool, meeting rooms, and restaurants. To do anything, you have to walk outside and walk or drive to the facilities. So if you want to be overcharged for the room, charged extra for every amenity, and inconvenienced in accessing any of them, this is the place for you.

Reviews.Title: “It was alright”
Reviews.Author: cliffwy
Reviews.Content: The rooms were ok. I walked in and found a small spider in the bathroom. The toilet looked "used". The carpet must not have been vacuumed as I found a half eaten pretzel in the middle of the room. Parking (which I was not aware of) was $20 for one night (I heard it's $10/night for extended stays). I was not expecting to pay for parking. Shower was nice (rain shower), but the hot water ran out quickly. All in all, my stay was ok. I traveled there on business, but in the summer months, it would probably be very nice for a family as there is much to do there.

Reviews.Title: “Prepare to be gouged!”
Reviews.Author: Homelytraveler
Reviews.Content: Upon entering the property we were awestruck by the tropical island-like surroundings--truly believed we had made an excellent deal by selecting an Alaska Airlines vacation package including air fare and hotel. The photos we had seen online didn't actually do the place justice. We found ourselves surrounded by towering palm trees, huge flowering shrubs, natural-looking lagoons, ponds and fountains, with strategic patios on which to relax next to flowing waters. The curbside valets and bell staff were cordial and accomodating; however, our first nasty surprise came in the sumptuous lobby upon registering, when we learned that it would cost $20.00 per night-no exceptions--to park our rental car in front of our room--or anywhere on the property, in fact. The desk clerk informed us that this was clearly stated on their web site (news to us). With no other parking within a reasonable walking distance, we had no choice but to pay. This added another $100.00 to the cost of our five-day stay. After traveling since early morning, we were more than ready for lunch at 3 p.m. on the day of our arrival, and seated ourselves at the outdoor restaurant. Our hamburger and sandwich lunch with iced tea came to $50.00, (including a modest tip for modest service). We were even billed for refills on the tea! That was our first and last meal at the resort. The rooms are motel style. An inaccessable outdoor light shone through the door window all night long, making it impossible to truly darken our room. "Shabby chic" best describes the decor. This included the armoir holding the TV, fridge and our clothing, and shabby it was: the white finish was marred by nasty black marks at the base and appeared to be rotting in places. One drawer was askew, leaving nearly a one-inch gap above one side of the closed drawer, and using it was a chore at best. (With bilateral tennis elbow, I had to ask my husband to pull it out and push it back in.) The bathroom door molding was completely rotted away in places. The mirror over the single sink was lighted by two 52-watt bulbs (yes, that's 52)--good luck grooming with that kind of illumination. The weather that week was not conducive to lazing by the pool but , if memory serves, available television programming consisted of MSNBC, CNBC, CNN, Headline News, the Discovery and Disney channels, and the standard local network outlets --oh, and, of course, a pay-per-view movie channel; there was no channel listing on-screen or on paper; NBC had a distinct orange cast at all times; the audio interference was often so severe that it was impossible to follow the program. ABC was sometimes watchable, but often there was no picture. All of the channels featured annoying audio interference to varying degrees. We registered complaints the second, third and fourth days of our stay. "Engineers" came to our room twice to tell us someone was "working on the problem" but by the fifth and last day of our stay, nothing had changed. The concierge was available only to those standing in front of him. Calling on the phone meant sitting on hold until we gave up. and looked for other information resources. So, if you're thinking of a nice resort vacation at Paradise Point, be prepared to pay through the nose and be higly self-sufficient; don't be disappointed when your accomodations fail to be on a par with the lobby or the grounds.

Reviews.Title: “The resort and some other hints”
Reviews.Author: ac6
Reviews.Content: Just returned from a 7 night stay at the Paradise. Lovely grounds - 5 pools - the central one is heated - and a mini golf for the kids. The rooms are neat and clean. They are decorated with a "rustic" theme which to some may appear as "old worn paint" but is actually the theme. We had a basic room with 2 beds which also came with a table, fridge, and a safe. Our room was right across from the "adult" (18 and over only) pool which also had a hot tub. Open from 9am to 10pm. They did charge $20 extra for parking but can be bargained down to $10. The fitness club is an extra $15 a day. The resort is 40 acres of nicely landscaped roads and walking paths. It is also next door to a park with more walking paths. Most important it is centrally located between the various sites to see -- unlike the Coronado which is a traffic nightmare. The Fish Market (Upstairs is the more expensive Top of the Market) is a great restaurant near of the USS Midway. Around the corner along Mission Beach must try the "the mission" ---- for breakfast or lunch. Afterwards walk the boardwalk of Mission Beach. La Jolla is beautiful -- but get there early to get a parking spot.

Reviews.Title: “Not worth the money”
Reviews.Author: Jamie_Cincinnati
Reviews.Content: I stayed here for a conference. The conference facilities and food was pretty good. The grounds were nice and well-kept. The hotel rooms, however, were horrendous especially for the price. The first night, I was rudely awakened at midnight by lawn sprinklers going off in front of my door. In addition, I was awakened about every two hours because the smoke detector kept making noise. I called the front desk the next morning to let them know and they changed the battery. The small refrigerator was also very noisy and you could hear what was going on in your neighbor's room. In addition, at 7 a.m. on Friday morning I couldn't get any hot water. Friday night wasn't much better - although the smoke detector didn't make noise the room was still very noisy from other things. This place is definitely not worth the price and I wouldn't stay here for pleasure.

Reviews.Title: “A secluded, rustic resort.”
Reviews.Author: JamieD22
Reviews.Content: A great experience if the price is right. Keep in mind that anything the resort has to offer will come at a cost. Secondly, if you're expecting luxury, you'll be disappointed. I booked a room for 4 nights in January for my fiance and myself, so that we could get married on the property during our stay. That said, the grounds of the hotel are immaculate and masterfully kept. The rooms however are old, a bit out-dated, and would probably classify as "rustic" sooner than "nice." I might go as far as to say "cozy." The hotel is not for those who couldn't book their room at the Hilton but more for those who want a more secluded, outdoorsy, almost camp-like resort. The ammenities on the grounds are laughably expensive; the spa, the workout facility, the restaurants... there were too many alternatives in nearby La Jolla to spend money on the resort. There is a parking fee of $20 per day though the front desk charged us only $10 (due to the length of our stay). Other than that we were offered nothing special (which I found a bit odd considering the nature of our visit). We stayed in the "Lanai Garden" (base room) for 2 nights, then paid extra the last 2 nights to stay on the beach in the "Lanai Bayside." It was worth the extra $50 per night, and it took only a few minutes to coordinate, though I felt slighted having to pay - the resort was practically empty and again it would have been a nice gesture. All in all we had a very memorable visit. The hotel is centrally located but secluded from the surrounding attractions. My tip would be to take a drive north on Hwy 101, stopping off at all the quaint beach towns. Balboa park is a lot of fun, too, just get out & explore!

Reviews.Title: “Very good if you get a deal”
Reviews.Author: momdadkiddog
Reviews.Content: I've read the widely varying reviews on this resort. Now having stayed there, I think I can be helpful to sort out the disparities. First, I think it helps to know about the reviewer. I'm comfortable in a clean Motel 6, but stay about once every six months in $300 and up resorts. Cleanliness and no deferred maintenance is paramount to me. Service is important, but I'm satisfied if the resort "makes it right for mistakes, as long as there are only one or two that don't greatly affect the purpose for my stay. I hate overpaying, but don't mind paying a lot if I get something special for the price. So with that in mind... The first impression driving up to the resort is very impressive. You meander up a beautiful private drive, with well manicured and landscaped grounds. The check in building is OK. There was a snafu immediately at check-in. I couldn't determine if it was the fault of the resort or the agent, but all was straighten out ,with much apology, in about 1/2 hour, a bit long for a tired family. If you arrived on public transportation someone in an oversized golf cart will take you to your room. You'll need it. Even if you drive, ask for someone to guide you to your room, especially at night. You WILL get lost on your own. Because of the package I booked, our room was probably on the lower-end pricing end of what's available. Considering the on-line pictures, I was disappointed at the drive-up appeal of the bungalow: fronting on a parking lot, although concealed by some attractive landscaping. Once inside, I found the room small, but very appealing, recently updated, with warm materials, and thoughtful interior decorating. The bathroom was well-done. All was spotlessly clean. Ask for a room with a water view. Many rooms have none, despite what you'd think from their pictures. It looks like the water-view rooms would make most people very happy. We were in San Diego during record cold, so opted out of visiting the pools which looked attractive. There are two main restaurants. I highly recommend breakfast at the Barefoot Bar and Grill. It reminds me of some of the nicer open-air resort restaurants in Hawaii with surround-views of Mission Bay, sea-water pools containing large native fish, and ubigitous, gulls, terns, herons and egrets standing by ready for any scraps your children care to share. Food and service were excellent, but we chose a low-volume time to dine. I don't know if they get busy. The putt-putt course is a unique, natural grass course with some very long putting between holes. It looks entertaining. Great views of Mission Bay from the climb-up observatory. If you're taking kids to Sea World you can't get much closer than this resort. Service overall was fair, not great for the price. My impression is they're somewhat understaffed. For example we ordered room service that took over one hour, and they never responded to our call to pick up the tray. We called back to tell them we'd leave it outside and it remained there overnight - spread around and picked over by gulls. The overall quality is very good, but not Four Seasons good. If you haven't been to many high-end resorts I think you'll be delighted. If you're used to high end service you'll be a little or a lot disappointed. Bottom line. If you can get a deal, I think it's well-worth it. But if you'll pay much more than $150/night for the basic room, I'd shop.

Reviews.Title: “Do not think about staying here”
Reviews.Author: mille125
Reviews.Content: Where do I begin?? There were so many awful things that happened during this trip related to this hotel. I must start off by saying that I rarely write negative reviews. However, I feel that everyone needs to know about this place. 1) They charge $20 for parking when you park in a spot in front of your room. This is like a motel charging for parking...Ridiculous. 2) The beach is full of seaweed and look nothing like the website pictures. 3) It took them 3 hrs to bring us a crib and two highchairs. After a gentleman finally brought it, he refused a tip because he felt our service was bad. He was the only honorable person at the resort. 4) The toilets ran for 30 minutes after each usage. We could hear it in our rooms and the adjacent rooms. 5) We had a power outage in our room. The power clicked on and off for every 30 minutes all night long. Management refunded our money for the night of the stay. 6) Many of the usual amenities were not available because of offseason (ie pools were closed, etc.) These are the highlights...many..many other things went wrong as well (they had no hot water during a spa treatment).....This hotel is simply awful. I would have been better off at the Motel 6.

Reviews.Title: “Your Safety Doesn't Matter”
Reviews.Author: UDXMXJ
Reviews.Content: Paradise Point Resort and Spa, San Diego, CA Beware that the management at this resort does not care about your safety. While I was there in September of 2006 I fell on an eroded strip of grass and broke my wrist. This is a long narrow strip of grass between several units and the beach. My small grandchildren had also been tripping and falling in that same area. The only thing I asked of the resort management was that they rope off this area and get the grass filled in and fixed as soon as possible. As of January 2007, they have refused to acknowledge that this dangerous area is a hazard and have done nothing to eliminate the hazard for other guests. I have written twice to remind them of their moral obligation to ensure the safety of other guests but they have refused to act and have added insult to injury by inferring that my pain was distorting my evaluation of the situation. Can fourteen family members all staying at this resort and in this location all be wrong in their evaluation that the area is hazardous? The resort is also overpriced and the parking you pay for is a numbered spot beside your unit.

Reviews.Title: “Great Place!”
Reviews.Author: trip56
Reviews.Content: It was great place to stay. The cottage/room was just a walk to the beach. The drive to the cottage/room was a nice change from traditional hotels. There were heated pools and spa. Friendly and helpful hosts and crew. Lots of little lagoon and bridges for a nice walk. I specially enjoyed the Christmas lights they have by the registration building. A little bit pricey but it was worth the stay. Except the room only had two bath towels and a hand towel. The key didn't work an hour before check time so be careful being locked out.

Reviews.Title: “Wow, Yes!!!”
Reviews.Author: themusicman
Reviews.Content: We were looking for somewhere warm to relax before the real winter set in in Scotland and having visited San Diego in 1996 we decided on a return visit to the southern Californian city. Expedia took care of the booking and when we got to the hotel we were completely blown away by the 350,00 lights which had been erected and switched on for the Christmas period. It was almost unbelievable!! The welcome from the staff was warm and helpful and they remained so throughout our eleven night stay. We had been attracted by the fact that accomodation was in bungalows as opposed to rooms in a multistorey hotel and although the outside was rather unprepossessing, the facilities in the bungalow were very good. The resort itself was well laid out and with five swimming pools there was never a problem finding somewhere to have a dip even in December!! The temperatures were always in the low - mid 70s from about 8.30am until around 7.30pm so swimming was always an option. We did not hire a car as we wanted a relaxing holiday and we had discovered that the excellent public transport service passed the door of the resort. Buses nos 8 and 9 rune every 15 minutes during the day and approx 30 minutes in the evening and a 3 or 4 day pass was excellent value for $9 or $15. The city of San Diego was as good as we remembered it and the people were as friendly as the hotel staff. The Zoo in Balboa park, visits to Coronado and La Jolla were all highlights and we had a magnificent holiday. We cannot recommend this resort highly enough.

Reviews.Title: “It was Paradise..Don't Understand the Bad Reviews”
Reviews.Author: twodadsupnorth
Reviews.Content: We absolutely loved Paradise Point. We stayed from Christmas day to New Years day and had a great time. Our rooms were wonderful...modern, king beds, on the bay, separate living/dining room, two sinks, lots of closet space. We had room service a few times which was prompt. One of our tvs did not work when we checked in (late on Christmas night) and within 15 minutes of our call someone from engineering came and fixed it. We had a microwave and fridge in our room which was helpful as we were travelling with our 2 year old son. On check out day our bags were picked up promptly by bell staff and were waiting for us at the front desk when we checked out. Concierge was helpful and helped us book a rental car for our stay. We loved the pool areas, and the adult pool area was a nice break when we had grandparent babysitters. The location is very central--we visited Sea World, the Zoo, downtown, Carlsbad, Coronado..all within easy driving distance. The concierge has a great sheet of driving directions that makes getting around a breeze. We met lots of nice people here, many there with their kids like we were. All in all we had a great stay, and we will definitely visit Paradise Point again.

Reviews.Title: “Overpriced place”
Reviews.Author: prettee2000
Reviews.Content: We stayed 2 nights at Paradise Point. Though the concept of having a vacation resort is great, I don't think the resort came upto my expectations. The room we stayed in was with a double bed and looked decent. The bathroom and the vanity area had tiles on the floor. The floor was cold and I think the management should have atleast provided a foot mat. Also, I was really surprised that there was no waste basket in the bathroom! Like many of the reviewers have previously stated, the resort compasses a huge area and facilities are spread out. Though the list of facilities is long, not everything looks as appealing.. The spa rates were outrageous.... (a simple pedicure cost $60!!) and the observation tower looked like it had been consumed by rust and would collapse any minute!! The most ridiculous thing was that there was no wireless internet (even motels have them!) and if you needed to use the internet, it was a $10 fee/ day of using the DSL connection in your room! I personally would not visit it again.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Resort”
Reviews.Author: johnnyq627a
Reviews.Content: We stayed at Paradise from Thurs Dec 30 - Sun Dec 3. We were upgraded to a Garden Suite for no charge. The room was extremely large. It had a king bed, armoire with TV, couch with coffee table, breakfast table with four chairs, seperate room with a fridge and microwave, a large walk in closet, tub/toilet in seperate room, double sinks in seperate room. The room itself reminded me a lot of our stay in the Dominical Republic... a very tropical feel, as opposed to high end luxury. The parking fee was $20, but the Marriot in Mission Valley I stayed at the previous nights was $13, so not much different. The grounds were beautiful, lots of diverse plant life, many ponds and lakes with ducks which we enjoyed feeding. The small restaurant had a saltwater lagoon with huge yellowtail in it. Luckily I asked before I tried to fish. (I didn't realize it was a pet pond, I thought it was just an inlet from the bay). The breakfast was kinda lousy, we went to downtown/la jolla/ or oldtown for food. The lobby was beautiful, with fireplaces, which was nice since it was in the low 40's morning/nights when I was there. The first day we walked to SeaWorld, which was a bit of a hike (2 miles or 30mins). There were walkways the entire way and walking over the bridge provides a beautiful view. We took a quick walk on the beach one day, it was clean ... that's pretty much all I ask. Overall, I was extremely pleased with my stay at the resort. I have to imagine the poor reviews come from people who prefer Rtiz Carltons and Bellagio type resorts. This resort is NOT a RITZY place, it's more of a caribean laid back setting. If you go there expecting a relaxing place as opposed to high end lifestyle you will enjoy yourself.

Reviews.Title: “Not for the Business Traveler”
Reviews.Author: TMS08
Reviews.Content: I stayed at this resort for 3 nights while attending a business meeting. Upon entering the resort you are struck by its warm and tropical feel. Unfortunately, the sleeping rooms were not as wonderful. Their rooms are not made for business travelers. There was no distinct desk and the high speed internet access was located near the TV which meant you had to use the computer while sitting on your bed. Generally, the rooms did not appear to be overly clean. There were rust stains and other signs of dirt and/or age. The air condition was controlled by a unit in the room which was so loud that you had to turn the TV up to hear over it. When traveling for work the biggest test is whether you feel comfortable enough in a room to walk around in bare feet like you would at home. Let's just say I'm glad I brougt flip-flops. The conference facilities and catering was wonderful. However, the rooms certainly need work.

Reviews.Title: “Amazing time in Paradise!!”
Reviews.Author: justhetwofus
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at Paradise Point Resort for 3 days and were both super sad to leave. We made use of their bonfire pit (which was on the resort's private beach that was only a few steps from our room) and kicked up our feet and listened to the evening surf in front of our romantic bonfire made for two. We tried out both resort restaurants Baleen's and the Barefoot Grill and had wonderful food and service at both. Baleen's was classy and we dressed up and had pastas and wines at a table by their fireplace. Barefoot Grill was casual and we opted to sit outside and had fun trying out their selection of margaritas. Everywhere we looked on the resort there was another great private and comfortable nook to sit and read a book, enjoy the scenery, or feed the ducks (duck food sold conveniently in the resort gift shop). We had roomservice deliver breakfast to our room on the last morning of our stay and we bid a bitter-sweet goodbye to our little island paradise over a wonderful breakfast which we set up in our private patio and ate while watching families and couples playing/strolling/jogging on the beach. Although I found this resort quite romantic, I found it family friendly too. There was a good number of families with small children who looked like they were enjoying themselves as well. I'm sure it's a great convenience that the resort's just a 2 minute drive from Sea World too. The overall feel of the resort is sort of a rustic island paradise mostly meant for taking it easy. Rooms and furniture have an old worn feel. More for those looking for closest thing to barefoot in Hawaii than those looking for the Ritz Carlton. The privacy and scenery can be quite costly though so I don't think I'd go here at the height of vacation season where rooms like the one I was in are three times the price I paid. I stayed midweek and non-holiday so I felt I got a good deal and was well worth the price.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful”
Reviews.Author: reid18
Reviews.Content: I stayed here with my son for four days (my second visit). I can't believe some of the reviews. Did I stay at the same place? The setting is superb. From our garden room we had views across Mission Bay and we were just steps from the beach. We found the whole resort clean and tidy (rubbish, what rubbish?). It is an idyllic place to just chill out and relax. The grounds are superb and just great to wander around. We relaxed several times at the adult only pool, one of many pools dotted around the resort. We had it to ourselves most of the time. Our studio room was absolutely fine, very comfortable and clean. As one previous reviewer commented - the furniture is actually MEANT to look slightly shabby. It's not worn out, it's the style: But this is probably a hard concept for some people to take on board. All the staff we encountered were friendly and helpful. The only slight criticism I would have is that the Baleen Restaurant was very expensive and not really that good. On my previous visit two year's ago it was much better. The Barefoot Grill was good though. We had breakfast there in the sun with views across the Bay. All in all, I would recommend this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Loved it!”
Reviews.Author: hugjessie
Reviews.Content: I was nervous to stay at Paradise after some of the reviews I had read but I am so happy that I did....what a wonderful place! I was there for a group function and we had such a nice time. Our entire group was close together and it was so nice to be able to meet up on the beach for bonfires or to sit around the beautiful lagoon outside of our rooms. The front desk staff was very helpful and the bellman were very attentive to helping with bags and bringing us to our rooms. I cannot wait to stay at the resort again, a beautiful place!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Reviews.Title: “This place is an expensive dump”
Reviews.Author: H-Holly
Reviews.Content: We just returned from a 4-day stay at Paradise Point and I will never, ever stay there again. The first room they gave us smelled so bad I got a headache after 5 minutes of being in there. It smelled of sewage in that whole area of the property. I went to the front desk and complained and they gave me another room in a completely different area of the resort. It was barely acceptable. When we walked around the resort we saw garbage laying around. The ponds were covered with scum. Paint was peeling off the walls of most buildings. This place looks like it might have been nice about 15 years ago, but was bought by a slum lord who hasn't put a dime into since then. I was desperate for a cup of tea the first morning there so I went to their walk-up espresso cart and had to pay $3.50 for a cup of hot water and a tea bag. This place is a total rip off. Stay somewhere else.

Reviews.Title: “Warning: Chemical smell and allergic reacton”
Reviews.Author: LeisureErik
Reviews.Content: I stayed at Paradise Point as part of a convention that was being held at the resort. The resort is nice, but there was one major negative that caused me to have a terrible experience. When I got to my room late at night, I noticed a terrible smell. I thought that maybe the room was a smoking room and the smell was a deodorant to mask the smell of smoke. I travel almost every week on business, so have dealt with this before. I was too tired to switch rooms that evening, so went to sleep. I had a hard time sleeping and kept waking up with a burning sensation in my throat and a bad headache. I made it through the night and felt better after I got some fresh air the next morning. I also switched rooms. After a full day at the conference and feeling healthy again, I moved into my new room. Within 15 minutes, I had the same burning and headache. It was even worse than the prior night. I ended up checking out and staying at the Hilton at the airport. The management was reasonable and didn't charge me a penalty for cancelling. Also, they told me that they use a number of chemicals in the room. Clearly, I had some type of reaction to these chemicals. It has never happened to me before in nearly 20 years of business travel, so it is something unique to Paradise Point. Be careful, especially if you are bringing young children! Other than this, the place was reasonably nice. The rooms are large, though modestly appointed. The bathroom was adequate, with a nice shower head and good water pressure, but the decor was sparse and showing some signs of age. (I don't think the tubs and toilets have been upgraded recently.) The resort itself is very spread out and the only complaint I had is that it takes a long time to get from one place to another and that the rooms and roads are circuitous and poorly lit, so you can easily get lost at night.

Reviews.Title: “NOT a Resort”
Reviews.Author: Choice95
Reviews.Content: I came home determined to write a review but got busy. Maybe things are better now. "Misleading" is the best word I can use. The hotel lobby s well kept and impressive but that is all. The grounds and guest rooms are not maintained. The pictures on the web site are just false. Yes, the rooms are spacious but the ammenties are there but it is VERY MUCH OVERRATED. The rest of the property needs to catch up with the lobby and the pictures on the website!

Reviews.Title: “Not worth the money”
Reviews.Author: frappy
Reviews.Content: There is no way this place is worth the $250.00 per night. It is old, they try to cover up the place with paint and new carpet but the tub, tile around the tub, floors in bathroom and counters were old. The maid service was terrible, two hours to get towels when they had not returned the used ones they took during maid service. The room we had was next to the service entrance and you could hear the workers in and out. The food in the restaurant was over priced and the service was terrible. I travel three times a year on vacation with my family and this is no way any place I would recommend to any friends or family.

Reviews.Title: “Wouldnt reccomend”
Reviews.Author: Ed05
Reviews.Content: Stayed here after for three nights and was glad to leave. The rooms are tired and in need of a revamp - chipped furniture, dirty small patio area outside the room which I would not have sat in , and non working light bulbs not replaced during stay. Had room service one night, ( terrible soggy pizza) and the tray sat outside my room for two days.This was after placing an order only to be told we had the old room service menu and having to make a further two phone calls to get an updated version. No do not disturb signs in this place for some reason, so the maids constantly trying to look round the curtains into the rooms in the morning. Cleaning outside the rooms starts very early and noisily at 7am- just what you want ona vacation I liked the waterside restaurant, nice location especially in the evening, very friendly staff here. Didnt try the more expensive option. Staff seemed to be constantly moving round on golf carts- doing what I do not know. No pool side service- why? Probably acceptable if you have kids , get a good deal and are going to Sea World, which you can walk to- otherwise there is little reason to stay here.

Reviews.Title: “hell rather than paradise”
Reviews.Author: wonderjo
Reviews.Content: It was awful: as soon as we entered our room, we could check that the view over the lagoon was only for advertisement and not for us, we had a wall in front of us; while coming back and back twice or thrice to the desk, we could not find any improvement: and all the rooms proposed were ugly and stinking as a sewer; the desk word was that sea humidity combined to tapestry often resulted in such a drawback. We could check that some work was under way in some selected rooms to lay a new tapestry but it was not to our own benefit. very expensive anyway to spend 3 nights in this hell/paradise: my feeling is also that going through an expedia reservation often ends in an underrated dwelling. don't forget that since you are far from any out of Paradise breakfast table, you'll have to "profit" from an expensive breakfast in this paradise.

Reviews.Title: “Great for families. "OK" overall”
Reviews.Author: Winfield_Travel
Reviews.Content: We stayed at Paradise Point for about a week after the Labor Day holiday. The property is great for families, as there are lots of kids and kid-friendly activities (feed the ducks, swimming pool a 0 grade that eventually deepens). They set up a Pack and Play in the very large walk-in closet that became our 2 y/o's "own room." Hotel grounds were nice, but not "pristine" or particularly serene. It was definitely tropical in feel, but there's no mistaking it for a secluded island retreat, as some have suggested. The tropical theme does not extend into the guest rooms, which is a little strange. The decor is light and colorful, but much more reminiscent of Cape Cod than Hawaii. Some have criticized the armoirs in the room as old, dirty and in need of a paint job. That's the way it's SUPPOSED to look, but it is not particularly aesthetic. The room was large enough, the furniture too big for the space. We found the a/c to be effective at cooling, albeit loud. Same goes for the mini fridge-- also keeps you up at night. Location was nice. Especially convenient to Sea World, though it would be nice if they ran a shuttle. I can understand why people are upset at having to pay $20 a night for parking (they comped us b/c we checked in as the place emptied out after the Labor Day holiday), but it allows them to advertise competitive room rates. We did not have problems with light flooding the room in the a.m. We had blackout curtains on your sliding glass door and a wood front door. But I noticed not all rooms were this way. We also didn't have dirty carpet, as some complained of. Paradise Point offers a very interesting hotel concept. It is in need of some updating, but overall we enjoyed ourselves. However, if you're paying well above $200 a night on average, you are not getting a good deal for your dollar.

Reviews.Title: “Guests to pay $20/day for parking”
Reviews.Author: kg95
Reviews.Content: This resort is ok, but if you don't want to have to pay $20 a day for parking (even though you're a "guest") or pay $10 a day for internet, then you probably don't want to stay here. The room has a country feel to it, which isn't bad. And, if you stay in the Lanai Patio rooms, then all you get is the window to your patio and no other windows. If I had seen that on their web site, we probably wouldn't have taken it. But we've decided to take the attitude of "we don't want to spend the whole time in the room anyway." But, if you like a little more in your room, then you may want to dish out a little more $$ for a room with a little more. Like I said, the resort is ok for what it is.

Reviews.Title: “Paradise Lost”
Reviews.Author: travellingman2
Reviews.Content: Had 2 rooms (792-793) on Hibiscus Lane. We booked for 3 nights (Sept 6-7-8). Was very specific and had requested way in advance for adjoining renovated rooms having heard some of the comments on Trip Advisor. Check in experience on the night of 9/6/06 should have forewarned me. The rooms are so oudated, carpets are so badly stained, grout dirty, toilets espcially behind the toilet seat grimy. We always bring Lysol and clean for ourselves anyway., but this was too much .The beds were very high to reach. The furniture including nightstands were extremely small and the armoire needed major repainting. When I complained about the condition of the 2 rooms, the front desk said this was the "rustic look". Looked filthy and worn down to me. Very different from what the web-site looked. If you are in to the "Cottage worn-down distressed look", this is the place for you. As far as I was concerned the rooms needed MAJOR renovation and upkeep. The new conference hall (Sunset Ballroom) where we had our meeting is beautiful and sparklingly clean. The deck facing the bay was gorgeous. Alas if only the guest rooms were of the same class and vintage, we would have stayed all the 3 nights. We just couldn't stand it so we had to hassle & check out the next day and stayed at the nearby Hilton San Diego Resort which was cleaner, brighter and easier to manage. The Hilton San Diego Resort was just purchased by the same owner of the Paradise Point.

Reviews.Title: “Just what we needed!”
Reviews.Author: CEBB
Reviews.Content: Our family of four (Dad & Mom -40 yoa & twin sons - 5yoa) stayed at Paradise Point 8/28-9/1 in a Lanai Garden room-King bed & queen sofa bed; desk/table w/ 3 chairs; armoire with TV and smal refrigerator; large walk-in closet with luggage racks, plenty of hangers & space and a programable safe; split bath (tub and toilet separate room from sink and large countertop); and a nice, big patio w/ two adirondak chairs and table surrounded with foliage and flowers. Very private. Some room patios are right on sidewalks, roads, walkways and parking lots.
